repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:  Cannot allow mouse interaction for non-focusable float window.
Solution: Add a "mouse" field to float window config.

Extracted from #30542, removing the callback part.

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -129,7 +129,12 @@
 ///            fractional.
 ///   - focusable: Enable focus by user actions (wincmds, mouse events).
 ///       Defaults to true. Non-focusable windows can be entered by
-///       |nvim_set_current_win()|.
+///       |nvim_set_current_win()|, or, when the `mouse` field is set to true,
+///       by mouse events.
+///   - mouse: Specify how this window affects mouse events.
+///       Defaults to `focusable` value.
+///       - If false, mouse events ignore this window.
+///       - If true, mouse events interact with this window normally.

comment_data.body:
> window ignores mouse events.

I don't think this is correct. This seems to suggest that the window still receives out events but they are no-op, but in fact mouse events completely pass through the window.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -129,7 +129,12 @@
 ///            fractional.
 ///   - focusable: Enable focus by user actions (wincmds, mouse events).
 ///       Defaults to true. Non-focusable windows can be entered by
-///       |nvim_set_current_win()|.
+///       |nvim_set_current_win()|, or, when the `mouse` field is set to true,
+///       by mouse events.
+///   - mouse: Specify how this window affects mouse events.
+///       Defaults to `focusable` value.
+///       - If false, mouse events ignore this window.
+///       - If true, mouse events interact with this window normally.

comment_data.body: No. There is no such thing as "treating" mouse events if it doesn't receive any.

I intentionally used two different names for the fields in `ScreenGrid` and `WinConfig`, because otherwise it's too easy to confuse them as the same field. In this PR they indeed have the same value, but in #30542 they didn't.

That's a bit pedantic though. Being technically correct leads to awkward documentation without any benefit AFAICT. It is strange to think of a window as "affecting mouse events", why would plugin authors need to know the implementation details?

comment_regular_data.body:
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/30542#issuecomment-2419095045 answers my initial question:

> I'm also starting to doubt whether the callback is needed at all, as after #30741 is implemented, `vim.on_key()` along with `mouse = true` can kind of already achieve what the callback does.

Somewhat of a one-way door, unless we define `mouse: Object` in this PR, so that we can extend it later? 

Or we can relax `:help api-contract` to allow "widening" of types.
Dict fields are not part of the API contract.

> Dict fields are not part of the API contract.

? We can't remove dict fields or change their types in a backwards-incompatible way (e.g. number => string), so clearly they are part of the contract, though maybe it should be more explicit.
Hmm, I mean, they are not a part of the signature. If a Dict field that accepts a boolean is extended to also accept a callback, it's a backward-compatible change.

> If a Dict field that accepts a boolean is extended to also accept a callback, it's a backward-compatible change.

I think we should formalize that and also extend it to the function parameters/signature. They are equivalent in practice.

I'll do this in an upcoming PR/proposal.

FYI, On `nvim_open_win()` with `mouse = true, focusable = false`; if you left click on the floating window, the floating window gets focus, can edit/select. Isn't this wrong since `focusable` is `false`? You can use `vim.fn.win_gotoid()` to focus the window.

BTW, this is is not an issue for the popup window compatibility code since it consumes/discards these keys in a `vim.on_key()` callback. (Assuming that #30741 gets a fix.)

> FYI, On `nvim_open_win()` with `mouse = true, focusable = false`; if you left click on the floating window, the floating window gets focus, can edit/select. Isn't this wrong since `focusable` is `false`? You can use `vim.fn.win_gotoid()` to focus the window.
> 
> BTW, this is is not an issue for the popup window compatibility code since it consumes/discards these keys in a `vim.on_key()` callback. (Assuming that #30741 gets a fix.)

Hmm, I initially intended that for the callback case, not the `true` case, so maybe the callback is needed after all.

> initially intended that for the callback case

I can verify that returning `false` from the callback prevents a click from focusing. Instead of a `boolean` could have `mouse=` take a three value enum, for example: `ignore`, `click_will_focus`, `click_will_not_focus`.

title: feat(float): allow enabling mouse for non-focusable window
